One of your agents, posing as a Druchii, stirs the cauldron of hate. Fostering resentment between {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} with lies both white… and dark.

While they can be blunt, the Asur tend to veil insults through the arts. In the name of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}, commission a particularly stinging song about {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}. Don’t forget a catchy chorus to ensure it travels beyond court.

Not all brave Asur are on the battlefields, some commit to a covert life hidden in Druchii society for the good of Ulthuan. This one has taken the role of paramour and can influence through bed sport, suggesting to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} that {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} is not an ally but a foe.

{{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} has the manners of a drunk Dwarf! Such a lack of eloquence does not go unnoticed. Of course, this may have been exacerbated by potion poured into their wine. Nevertheless, it reflects badly on the host, {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}.

While frowned upon in Ulthuan, hiring a Khainite Assassin is common practice in Naggaroth, so let us put a contract on {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}; failure is irrelevant as long as {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} is implicated.

Have our servants talk to the serfs of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}, let them spread vicious gossip about the plans of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}. Such talk shall quickly work its way up to the Nobles.

The simplest ploys are often the most effective. Through the chatter of court, let it be known that {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} have been overheard defaming Finubar, wondering if he is up to the duties that come with the crown.
Steal Their Green

A new training regimen for your Heroes teaches them to veil their intent beneath a sheen of civility. After all, a killer with the manners of a rabbit is the most dangerous kind. The chances of successful Hero actions have now improved.
One of the great mountains of the Old World has erupted, bringing about a fiery hell. Even the waters boil and everything within proximity to the volcano has been reduced to ashes.
One of the oldest entries in this Dwarfhold's Book of Grudges has been struck out. A great feast is held to celebrate!
Mortal World's Torment
Mortal World's Torment

As the agent descends into the tomb, the sounds of battle ring out. A band of Lizardmen is locked in mortal combat with a host of crypt-horrors, and they are losing. As the Undead begin to overwhelm the reptiles, the agent spots a standard-bearer scurrying for the entrance with a clanking sack of relics on his back. He slays the creature and takes the trove. Surveying the limits of the chamber, he also realises that Alcadizaar's sarcophagus is missing. Hefting the sack, he exits the tomb and sets out to rendezvous with Arkhan.

To impress upon visiting aristocrats to our fair cities, our merchants showered lavish products upon them at discounted prices. Although this affected their profits, the quality of their goods has been praised the world over.

The agent hovers at the entrance until the clamour dies down, then steals inside to witness a scene of devastation. Lizardmen corpses litter the main chamber, but the Crypt Horrors have returned to their swaying, quiescent state. Sensing some kinship with the agent perhaps, they do not attack, but point mournfully toward an alcove where clearly a fine sarcophagus once lay. Alcadizaar's coffin has been spirited away. Tearing a symbol from the tunic of a dead Lizardman, your agent sets out to bring Arkhan the news.

column1: Arkhan is beside himself with anger. What could the perfidious Lizardmen want with Alcadizaar's remains? He smells some species of dark scheme afoot, and demands the Liche Priests bring him news of these interlopers. Through divine communion, the Scavenger-God Ualatp reveals to them the location of the looters. Arkhan wastes no time, and sets out with his army to wrest Alcadizaar's remains from the Lizardmen.

The gods of your enemies have directly intervened in our interests. Sowing destruction across our realm, how do we confront a god's wrath?

The Geomantic Web pulses erratically for a moment, as if something unearthly had touched it. The Mage-Priests mutter of an ill presence, though they cannot divine the source; however, Chaos corruption has now increased factionwide…

Manipulate a Dreadlord to believe that {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} is working hand-in-gauntlet with {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} at court, thus forcing them apart.

There is a constant fear that anyone in Ulthuan could be one of the Witch King’s agents in deep cover. It is almost too easy to lay a whispered suggestion that the life partner of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} takes orders from Naggarond. Just ensure they know the rumour came from {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}.

To accuse {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} of worshipping the gods of the underworld is a serious charge. Although not technically illegal, it is frowned upon, and the loss of standing in the Phoenix Court will be quick. So, proof is needed, which is why you have installed a statue of Atharti at the accused estate, with a note of appreciation from {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}.

We have many relics in our archives, trinkets to us but sacred for others. A gift given to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}, will make them more receptive to our scheme of including {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} in the next phase.

Diverting an enemy into the ambush range of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} is the first part of the ploy; letting them keep the gold we planted on the convoy will lead them to a more favourable relationship with {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}, whose sigil is stamped into the hoard.

The one thing your kind loves as much as war is poo. You pile it high, building your huts or fashioning it into idols of Gork or Mork. Trouble is, that stuff gets hot when there's a large mound of it, creating a stinky gas which can explode… and has!

The Undead legions are immortal and immune to mortal concerns, such as disease. But the Chaos God Nurgle has a strange sense of humour, and so has blessed the lands with Grave Rot, a blight that quickens the decomposition process, meaning our troops are literally falling apart...
You take as many of the artefacts as you can carry and exit the vault. In the light of day you quickly realise that they are nothing more than worthless reproductions.
As your men begin their search, there is the sound of giant gears whirring into life. The entrance to the vault is suddenly blocked by a huge boulder!
The vault is likely riddled with traps! You cautiously back out, informing your retainers to mark the location on the map. Sadly, you are unable to sell the information.
While the treasures are tempting, no one in their right mind would leave them unguarded, surely?
You take as many of the artefacts as you dare and run from the vault. The desire for Lustrian artifacts means you will be able to command a high price for them.
Ignoring the tempting artefacts, your retainers soon find chests filled to the brim with gold, hidden at the back of the vault.
The vault is likely riddled with traps! You cautiously back out, informing your retainers to mark the location on the map - most treasure hunters are always happy to pay for information such as this.

The Druchii are keen users of poison, so we shall spike the food of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}. Not to kill, but to give a nasty ache. When suspicion falls upon the cook, let us ensure they are in {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}’s thrall.

The Cults of Pleasure are insidious. The gossip at court is that {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} attended a party hosted by {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} and the excesses witnessed were scandalous. The talk is untrue, of course, but the more they deny, the faster the rumour spreads.

The most effective way to damage relationships is to insinuate rather than use a Dawi’s bluntness. A half-jape to a prince here, a missive sent to an outer kingdom that doesn’t give the full story there… soon there is suspicion between {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}. As we intended.

Our embassies are often thought of as neutral ground to even the most hated of foes. Nothing could be further from the truth, obviously, but we control the environment and manipulate everything from ambience to the subject of conversation, ensuring that {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} are more predisposed to each other.
Chitter-Chatter
The Council’s Scorn

Nothing fosters relations than the death of a common foe. So, sending hated corpses to both {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}, and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}, each with missives attached to the bodies claiming credit, should fool these two factions into strengthening their bonds.
A Pain in the Back
You help the Shaman to his feet. Bizarrely, instead of trying to kill you, he chants something strange instead, before capering off into the sunset!
You warily approach the unconscious Shaman and search his body. The search is less than successful, and you may never feel clean again!

After much incoherent gibbering, you decide to cut the Shaman loose and he capers away. That turns out to be the wrong move - you soon realise that the thieving git has picked your pockets whilst making his exit!
These are Greenskins we're talking about - it could easily be a trap! It would be best if you didn't approach the campfire and considered moving on to another ruin altogether.
You help the Shaman to his feet. He chants something strange, and suddenly your hands are overflowing with gold! It's almost tempting not to kill him...
You cautiously approach the prone Shaman and search his body. Fighting the urge to vomit, you find a few trinkets and beat a hasty retreat.
You tie up the Shaman and interrogate him. His babbling is incomprehensible, but he does produce a magical item from the folds of his robes.

Another makes a claim on the Sword of Khaine. Rituals of consecration are under way - soon the sword will fall into enemy hands!
After a few days you still haven't heard from the expert you hired. When you send someone to investigate, they discover a corpse and bloody automaton tracks leading from the house.
You manage to find someone willing to buy the device, but it explodes during the trade. A lucky escape - fortunately only the buyer is killed this time.

As far as you can tell the wretched thing has no purpose. You order a retainer to take the biggest axe they can find and dismember the automaton, making as much noise and mess as possible in the process.
The Dwarfs waste their own time and that of others with such things. You have no use for their strange follies, so walk away.
The expert you hired is able to safely crack open the automaton and study it. It doesn't appear to serve any useful purpose but there are those willing to pay handsomely for a curio such as this.
You never work out what the purpose of the device is, but nevertheless manage to find someone willing to buy it. Oh well, there's one born every minute!
The automaton falls over on its side and explodes, destroying a nearby wall. The explosion reveals a chest full to the brim with exactly the sort of treasure you have been seeking all along!

Our scouts have located a vast graveyard containing the graves of many fine warhorses. The bones are well preserved and may still be strong enough to serve us - we should raise these creatures from their slumber to strengthen our cavalry even further.

Send a message of greeting and friendship… and a Warptoken bribe to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}. At the same time, send the same message to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}. It’s the simplicity of the strategy that is its strength.

Your people have unearthed a rift in your lands, linking it to the realm of the Gods themselves! The blood you have spilt has indeed won their favour, for now your warriors can soak up divine power directly from this rift, restoring their vitality, closing their wounds and infusing them with new strength to bring further death and destruction to your enemies.
The Great Council

The Hold's Slayers are summoned to Karak Kadrin to worship at the foot of Grimnir's Statue and then onto a great pilgrimage to seek out their death. To try and stop it risks forcing them to break their oath - no Dwarf would ever consider that!
The grim skull-adorned temples that dot the land grow restless with power. We should use this event to our advantage!
Closer inspection reveals the bodies are merely corpses propped up on sticks. You pull them down and give them a decent burial.
Repeated volleys fail to fell the Unliving enemy. Your troops waste far too much ammunition on a seemingly simple task.
Whilst you search elsewhere, rumours of the Undead presence spreads. Your people are outraged that you would place plunder above their safety.
You stand to gain nothing from engaging the Undead, except perhaps joining them somewhat swifter than planned!
Upon closer inspection you discover they are merely corpses propped up on sticks, intended to protect something. Investigation of the ruins reveals a small hoard of ritual currency hidden within.
You order your troops to attack from range. With impressive precision the Undead are taken down in one volley. This remarkable feat cheers the troops and improves their leadership.
It seems that whatever the Undead are guarding has already been looted - the land around the building has been picked clean.
Master Mason

Who knows more about the intrigues and secrets within the dread citadels? The advisors? The paramours? It is the torturers, of course, for they get the unvarnished truth. And if a certain torturer is in our employ they can report to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and encourage stronger ties with {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} using what they learnt during recent ‘extractions’.

Finubar’s war council is not an official organisation, more the Phoenix King’s close associates that guide and advise on matters of war. To be invited into the council is a great honour, so engineer {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}’s participation with {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} to improve their relations.

Taking on a ward or squire from another house is a good way of exerting soft power and strengthening lasting bonds between two houses or kingdoms. And so {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} has taken a princeling of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}.

We offer our services as a neutral party to negotiate a trade agreement between {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}. While our factors smile and encourage, they will be briefing against the interests of both.

{{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} has been specifically forbidden to act this way due to a pact signed by {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}. They have done no such thing of course, but our agents will tell the signee otherwise.

Wagons full of imperial goods frequently depart to foreign lands. A particularly large convoy disappeared, however. An investigation found the merchants and guards tied to trees and all the wagons plundered. The foreign lord denies any responsibility, but even a child knows that he is to blame for not keeping the roads clear.

A noble has managed to get himself in an embarrassing position. While a foreign dignitary was visiting, rumours started circulating that the noble was ridiculing the foreign delegation behind their backs and even hired a few jesters to give a private performance to mock them. Of course the noble denied it, but a few days later, a letter addressed to his wife surfaced, in which he expressed his disdain for the foreign dignitary. The delegation departed at once and spread the stories of their mistreatment back home.
Aim For The Head!

The wife of a local baron went missing without a trace. Weeks pass and searches return nothing. At the next full moon however, she is found dead and mutilated, hanging above the city gate. A letter was stuffed into her throat, with another faction expressing their hatred for the baron and claiming responsibility.
Knowledge of the Ancestors
Un-Peasant Business
Summon the Barrow Lords

The Twin-Tailed Comet arcs across the sky, a portent of great events. The Grand Theogonist has decreed this to be an ill omen. The comet is a warning that dire events are about to unfold, so your warriors are shaken and wary.

Sending {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} a list of their enemies and allies might be viewed with a certain suspicion, but if we make sure that {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} is in the allies’ column and add an enemy’s finger for verisimilitude, it might be believed.

The favour of Finubar will do wonders for any great Elven house. Ensure {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} receives patronage of the Phoenix King. Make it known through courtly gossip that it was fostered by {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}.

Unbeknownst to both, the shipment was intercepted en route, the gifts replaced by inferior copies in much lower quantities than promised.
A Tail of Two Cities
Mathlann’s Blessing

A caravan of precious baubles important to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} has gone missing. Our agents may have been responsible, but placing a few corpses belonging to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} should switch the blame to them.

A black-hobbed crow flies across the sky. In its wake come the beasts - reptiles, mewling cats, frenzied cattle, boars and others driven mad by something they have witnessed deep in the forest. The Famine-fiend stalks the land, emerging from the woods to leaving nothing but barren wastes and withered crops in his wake - for that is Slugtongue's curse.

Our trade routes are reliable and well-patrolled, if others want to use them they must pay. However, if we levy an additional tithe on {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and claim it is not our tax but one demanded by {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}, then relations will surely sour.

By planting some key pieces of evidence we can make it look as though {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} has been secretly worshipping a god that {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} finds particularly offensive. They will deny, and therefore look guilty.

While our ambassadors will not outright lie, they can target certain truths that may sound far worse out of context. And so we whisper in the ear of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} that {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} is not to be trusted.

Some dare defy us - we shall sour relations between {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetName}} of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}. In the long-term this will be far more destructive than a direct strike.
We Are Elf-Things
Threaten to Secede

Your allies have taken the Phoenix Gate. A valiant act, even if it deprives Avelorn of a righteous victory. Desperate not to offend the Everqueen, they have sent the reclaimed Shieldstone of Isha to your court in order to soothe any diplomatic wrinkles. After all, the Shieldstone belongs in your care.

Business at the Phoenix Court rarely happens while the king attends and deals with matters of state. It is when the Princes and Nobles splinter off to the alcoves and form informal sub-committees that things get done and so, over a few cups of wine, the binding of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} can begin.

To flatter and bribe is to ensure favour… delivering a gift of slaves to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} is regrettable for the captives, but if we frame this as {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}’s generosity it will strengthen the bond between these two factions, and be advantageous for us.

A careful discussion here, a subtle word over wine there, a smile that lingers, an eyebrow raised over a jest - all things men and Dwarfs would never pick up on. But for the Asur these are powerful social symbols, signs of alliance between two great houses of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}.

There are always enemies and annoyances for kings, queens and Dreadlords to overcome. Paying a contract to rid them of such a foe will leave {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} predisposed to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}, especially if we let it be known they hired the assassin.

The game of court has winners and losers; the fate of houses can be lost not just by invasion but by their Prince’s performance at court. Lending vocal support to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} at court will enhance their relationship with {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}.

Send {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} a corpse - but not one of our own. We shall send them back one of their own sleeper agents - not that they will know why they were killed. And on this corpse a message stressing the {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}’s predisposition to the Druchii.

Our kin take great store in words and verse. Send a poet to the estates of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} so that they may sing a verse, commissioned by us, of the great relations between them and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}.

A rumour has reached us, from far across the sea, that a Vampire has located a chamber of untold power, deep within Lustria. Although he failed to harvest its power for his own Unliving ends, the chamber collapsed, releasing the magic trapped within!
Sometimes, this is how it goes. Not all hunts are successful and the wise know when they are beaten. Perhaps a fortune will present itself further down the road?
After a thorough search it is clear that there are no spoils to be had. You turn your attention to the tracks but it is soon obvious that they are too faded to follow.

Following the tracks you come across a small band of treasure hunters encamped a short distance away, their wagons bursting with chests. You chase them off with ease and claim their haul for yourself.
A travelling merchant passes through the ruins and you capture and question him. He offers useless rumours and little else. You decide to relieve him of his goods to teach him a lesson.
Determined to find something, you hire a group of skilled - and expensive - treasure hunters to search through the ruins. They are soon forced to admit that they too are unable to find anything.
The tracks are confusing and double back on themselves several times. In the bewilderment, you get turned around and eventually lose the trail altogether.
You setup a makeshift barricade on the edge of the town and await for your predecessors to return. After days of fruitless waiting you finally admit defeat and leave.

A more overt attack: strike with Shadow Warriors, kill the allies of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} as they watch and then give {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} a friendly wave before disappearing back into the night. It will not be the dead that they focus on but the wave, which will bring down a cloud of suspicion and paranoia.

It seems that the process of transmutation is dangerously unpredictable. Gelt's experiments triggered an explosion which he barely survived, he is a veteran of such occurrences. However, his first-hand experience of the forces involved gives him an insight into an artefact that may reduce the risk.

What do we have before us but a lump of purest green? Taking Warpstone from Skaven is one of the greatest crimes - killing their kin or allies is a minor annoyance but stealing their Warpstone will get a furious response. And so we shall purloin the green of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}, leaving ‘evidence’ that {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} are the thieves.

Despite the Vampires' hatred of Nagash, his influence is inextricably linked to all creatures of Undeath. Some say his dread soul is abroad, bound to a lost relic until a vessel can be found. Until then, his whispering can be occasionally heard upon ethereal winds, augmenting Undead puppets with a jerky speed.
A Wrong Put Right!

The forest provides for those who do it great service. The Lords and Ladies of the realms of Athel Loren are chosen nobility, provided for greatly by the spirits of the forest. Those who work in more insalubrious capacities are still offered succour by the woods, for their all-the-same important service to the realm.

A highborn Lord of Ulthuan has been captured along with his honour-guard. Naturally, they are being paraded around this province in chains before their inevitable - and exquisitely slow - public execution. The local inhabitants are ecstatic at this delicious turn of events, resulting in local improvements to public order and army leadership.
Da Great Green Prophet
Count Mannfred pays the Necromancer's price, but has no regrets when he lays eyes on the tome. He recognises it as being one of the nine Books of Nagash, authored by the Great Necromancer himself.
The deckhands were diggin’ all through the night, ‘til their rusty spades clanked against an old chest buried in the dirt. The treasure has been found!

Epilogue
In preparation for the slaughter to come, Tzeentch has favoured one of our Champions with a gift.
Grave Rot

Battle is a blood-soaked affair. Limbs severed, bones exposed; men left for dead in the cruor-soaked fields amongst scores of fallen friends and enemies. Strong weapons, forged with time, sweat and expertise, mark the difference between victory and defeat. A good sword cuts clean through bone, severing heads and limbs, where lesser weapons will merely maim. As instability grows across the world, so too does man’s bloodlust and his desire for war and carnage on an ever-grander scale.

The Greenskins are famous for having all manner of monstrosities in their despicable ranks, including the lumbering Giants that follow them to feast in battle. Having heard of one very belligerent Giant called Blorgar the Mad Titan terrorising the Grey Mountains, you set out to slay the leviathan for a great sacrifice, for what can be more impressive than bringing down a legendary descendant of the long-forgotten Sky-Titans?

column1: Once you’d arrived in the Grey Mountains, however, Blorgar was nowhere to be seen. The only chance of gaining any useful information of the Giant’s whereabouts lay with a Bretonnian herb collector who’d allegedly stumbled upon an underground lair while spelunking nearby. Unfortunately this Bretonnian had been taken hostage by some nasty Goblins on a recent raid. The importance of the information known to him is crucial to complete the hunt, so a Hero was sent into the gobboes' camp to steal him back.
Your servant dumps the hog-tied Bretonnian herb collector at your feet, along with some loot he managed to steal on his way out.
column2: true

The last Cold One spawning yielded a rare strain, gifted with some notion of your venerable race's plight in their tiny brains. These beasts are so eager to fight for you that they barely need taming, and their urgency means that friendly infantry must trot to keep up. As a result, recruitment costs for Cold One cavalry units have fallen and army movement range has increased factionwide.
Workshop Explosion

The easiest way to manipulate the Skaven is to kill an ally or vassal of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and then leave the blade in its back, ensuring the traitorous dagger is etched with the sigil of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}.
Mutual Enemy

The favour – or lack thereof – of the Lords of Decay can easily shatter alliances. By circuitous means, make it known that {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} has fallen afoul of the Council of Thirteen’s wrath due to the machinations of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}.

Like igniting damp wood, spreading whispers of treachery throughout the Skaven clans is hard at first, especially for an Elf…but once the notion takes hold, once the wood begins to burn, it will spread like wildfire. Hence the rumours that {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} plans to betray {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} will quickly take hold.
Ambassador, you are Spoiling Us

As Spring finally bursts forth across Athel Loren, the deep chills of Winter retreat and life is given free reign once more. The forests bloom, verdant and lively. The boughs spread, the vines grow, and life explodes from the Deepwood once more…
With the funds secured, the Emperor orders his factors to secure the necessary rare materials so that the required additions to the astrolabe can be made.
The Ruinous Powers demand a large sacrifice of blood. The altars must be drenched in it or we will suffer a loss of favour!

Whilst excavating the Tomb City of Lybaras, our slave workers have uncovered scrolls detailing tactics, formations and manoeuvres not used for hundreds of years. There is much to be learned from this ancient way of battle - our enemies will be surprised when they die!
A part of the Dwarfhold, a lost area under the clutches of urks for many years, has been reclaimed. The Clans are already setting up undertakings in the new areas.
False Spawning
What is Isha’s is Yours

Blackpowder should be kept dry and away from open flames until used in cannons and such. Of course, it needs to be stored somewhere, just as long as no careless fool walks into the store with a torch or lantern…
Amidst the banging of tankards on the feasting tables, and raucous cheers and ribald chants, a storied hero of the Hold is risen up to the rank of Thane.

A nexus of Dark Magic surrounds us, bolstering our might and breathing unlike into anything you so choose. It is as if Geheimnisnacht is happening every night! We must use this blessing of dark intent while it remains!
Troll Migration

In the year 2429 Marienburg seceded from the Empire due to the selfish designs of the Burgomeisters. And now, mere decades later, another province dares to demand the same…

Against the boundaries of the Waystone fence, interlopers have come with their weapons of war. They brought destruction and vandalism to Athel Loren, before retreating like craven cowards when the forest stirred. Athel Loren demands vengeance, and would have you exact it.

A Cold One breeder, reputed for his voracious pit-fighting animals, has exploited his trade-contacts to acquire certain rare fungi used by the Night Goblins. Thus dosed, his enraged creations are unstoppable against regular stock. In fact the compound is so effective than none will now bet against the beasts; there's just no sport in it! The pit-owners refuse to field them and sales have fallen off a cliff, so the breeder has offered you his surfeit of reeking 'shrooms. The answer, quite obviously, is "Yes!" Duly dosed, his Cold One units now have enhanced melee attack capabilities factionwide.

Many conflicts are won or lost on the strength of the first, vicious charge. Men are sent flying from the battlefield, often in pieces, even before the savagery of melee begins. A well-timed charge shatters enemy morale, as well as bodies. Blood and sweat may coat the victors, but victory is always painted in colours such as these. Those at the head of the charge seek ever greater thrills, ever more bloodshed. As the battles become bigger, the body count grows higher and the trickles of blood become ever-flowing rivers of red.
Honour of Khorne
Sword of Khaine

A fashion for devising new and more exquisite forms of torture has developed among the lower ranks, and they are practicing it every chance that they get! A tongue under duress may reveal many secrets, after all. As one might expect, the income from raiding and sacking has increased factionwide.
Sacrifice the barbarian to Phakth, the God of Justice, and request a boon.
Flay the flesh from his bones and press him into eternal service.
Warpstone Showers
Infamy Rank Increased

The raging Sea-God, Stromfels, has gone missing, perhaps blown too far south by the arcane tempest that is consuming the world. With his absence, the Great Ocean is becalmed. The denizens of this world sense an opportunity - it is now no longer for the Elves to dominate the seas alone. Other powers seek to ply the oceans, hunt for treasures and expand their empires abroad. However, they must not mistake a calm sea for a safe one - there are still countless dangers lurking in the deeps!

Send captured Skaven to the Slann as a sacrificial gift to the Old Ones, and their snake god in particular. This should please {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}; imply the sacrifices came from {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} to bolster their relations.

We need a more stable relationship between {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}. A few new hieroglyphs in these ‘ancient’ plaques should be enough of a catalyst.

If we tell the gullible reptiles that an alliance between {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} is part of their Great Plan then they will action it. If they question the provenance of such a claim, then say it was on some ancient scroll or other.

Before you could reach the sea monster’s corpse you were suddenly accosted by a horde of Undead pirates also staking a claim to the potentially valuable remains. After dispatching them in the ensuing sea battle, you looted their galleon’s coffers before sailing on to the beast’s remains, where your crew were able to cut open its belly and extract further wealth and treasures.

While sailing towards the wreckage of the ship from Marienburg, a galleon helmed by a hissing Vampire Admiral appeared in a cloud of broadside guns and cracking black powder weapons, blocking your passage. After defeating the Undead freebooter, you looted their galleon’s coffers before sailing on to claim the salvage from the Marienburg wreck for yourself.

Compelled by the eerie songs carried on the sea breeze, you ordered your crew to disembark onto the mysterious islet. Before you could start searching for treasures, however, you are set upon by some Vampire pirates who seemed to have appeared out of nowhere. The songs of the cursed Syreens were obviously a trap! After defeating the Undead freebooters controlling them, you looted the Vampire’s moored galleon before claiming all the salvage on the island for yourself.

A corpse of such a size does not go unnoticed by the brigands of the sea, and sure enough on your way to the monster’s remains you are accosted by a Vampire Admiral’s fleet. After dispatching them in the ensuing sea battle, you looted their galleon before sailing on to the leviathan's remains, where your crew were able to cut open its belly and extract further wealth and treasures.

As you approached the wreckage, a galleon of Undead pirates appeared in a cloud of broadside guns and hissing black powder weapons, seeking to claim the sunken ship’s treasure for themselves. After defeating the Undead freebooters, you looted their galleon’s coffers before sailing on to claim the salvage from the sunken ship for yourself.

Before you can set foot upon the island, you are set upon by a Vampire Admiral who had arrived there just before you and was bolstering his forces with the reanimated corpses of the shipwrecked dead rotting amongst the rocks. After defeating the Undead freebooters, you looted the Vampire’s moored galleon before claiming all the salvage on the island for yourself.

The rival salvagers you spotted turned out to be a freebooting horde of Undead pirates. As you approached the putrid remains, they turned their guns and cannons on you. After dispatching them in the ensuing sea battle, you looted their galleon’s coffers which had recently been filled with trinkets and valuables extracted from the dead beast’s belly.

Such vast wealth does not go missing out on the open ocean without pirates catching wind of it, and before long a galleon helmed by a particularly belligerent Vampire Admiral appeared in a cloud of broadside guns and hissing black powder weapons, blocking your passage. After defeating the Undead freebooter, you looted their galleon’s coffers before sailing on to claim the salvage from the convoy for yourself.

Before you can set foot upon the island, you are set upon by a Vampire Admiral who had arrived there just before you and was bolstering his forces with the reanimated corpses of the dead crewmen rotting on the beaches. After defeating the Undead freebooters, you looted the Vampire’s moored galleon before claiming all the salvage on the island for yourself.

The pirate cove contained great wealth in the form of treasures and items stolen from across the four corners, but getting to it was no easy feat. When the Vampire Admiral at the helm of the black ship saw you approach, he immediately readied his horde of crewmen and darkling creatures for battle. After defeating the Undead freebooters, you ransacked their ship as well as the hidden cave to make for a plentiful hoard!
Cometh the Hour

A Dwarf Engineer and his surroundings have been immolated as he was experimenting with the potency of blackpowder. Underground fires are something the Dawi are used to dealing with, although significant damage was still sustained.
Cold Vengeance
Rancid Visitations
Death Night
Sword of Unholy Power
Dire Wolf Packs

There is no denying that the Knight is the pinnacle of the chivalric ideal, but arrogance must never get the better of honour. Some Knights, unfortunately, enjoy basking in their own glory a little too much…
Wurrzag, the prancing Shaman of Gork and Mork, visits to bring you ill omens and the scorn of the Green Godz. You must do something to get back in their favour.
Call to Dark Magic-Users
It's not necessary to expend too much effort when raising 'alf-buried corpses such as these; refillin' the ranks 'as never been so easy. Rissssssssse, me 'earties! Risssssssssse!

The reptiles’ reliance on prophecy and stellar arrangements make then susceptible for subtle manipulations. Using the Wind of Azyr we can slightly alter the skies and bring the Lizardmen to the conclusion that relations between {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} should be improved.

Alberic of Bordeleaux has dreamed of a life spent questing, yet when his father died he was thrust unexpectedly into the dukedom and has never been able to relinquish the awesome responsibility bestowed upon him. Yet opportunity has arisen at last in the form of dire tidings; the ancestral tomb of the Bordeleaux Dukes has been ransacked and amongst the items stolen is the Trident of Manann, said to be descended from the God of the Sea himself. Although horrified, Alberic is also instilled with an excitement. He knows he must rescue the relic and restore safety to the Dukedom, and so must investigate personally...

This season's harvest of Mad Caps has been disappointing. Then a rampaging Squig ate the few that were left. Without the mushrooms the Night Goblins can't make their infamous brew. Hopefully, the next batch will have a better yield.

An exotic caravan appears in mankind's realm, claiming to be from a foreign kingdom. Their goods are of high quality and their prices low. Intrigued by the opportunities of trade, merchants soon flock to the foreign territory in the hopes of securing a good deal.

Seemingly random lords received an invitation of a tournament hosted near Nuln. Upon arrival, they discovered that the tournament grounds have been set up and a foreign delegation was already present. But the foreigners claim they received a similar invitation, and no-one knows who is the host, nor how the tournament grounds were erected. A crate with a massive golden trophy is soon discovered. Both sides agree to compete honourably, with the winning faction receiving the trophy. After the festivities end, both sides agree they had a great time together and the tournament should become an annual event.
An influential Lord found a small box on the doorstep of his castle. Upon opening it, he discovered an exquisite jewel, along with a note from an unexpected foreign admirer...

Your people live in fear, for evil stalks fair Bretonnia. The Greenskins that infest the mountains and forests harass and raid the surrounding villages with ever-greater violence. Now they mass in the hills the people fear a greater incursion – control is decreasing across the land as a result. Hold out, if you think the kingdom robust enough – in the hope that they tire and skulk back to their hideouts – or lead a force to destroy their settlements, end their attacks and wipe them out for good.

One o’ your cronies ‘as sent an intriguing message, cap’n! It seems there be a mysterious pirate shadowin’ our movements, passin’ through the taverns along the coasts n’ askin’ suspicious questions, in no friendly terms! We'd best stay vigilant…

The winds are certainly provin' favourable this season, as we've been sailing at beam reach for days now. No matter our heading, we sail fast an' smooth. I think the Sea-God is at our backs - in fact, I'm sure of it!

Stolen from the Dark Elves, ancient Cold One eggs can be given to {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} as a gift from {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}. They are unlikely to dissuade the notion it was not due to their generosity.

An entire city district has been ransacked by unknown assailants said to have emerged from the sewers. Property has been destroyed and entire families have vanished - dragged into the sewers by hooded Daemons, if you believe the rumour-smiths...

The Twin-Tailed Comet arcs across the sky, a portent of great events. The Grand Theogonist has decreed this to be a good omen. Your warriors are elated that Sigmar looks upon them, and gird themselves for war.
Filled with Prayer
The Great Purpose
Get the Chisel
Gifts for the Old Ones

In a drive to improve combat stamina across your armed forces, the High Quartermaster has been experimenting with new ration combinations. His latest concoction is a bowel-addling patty of horse flesh, pickled fish and Forest Spider spinnerets, served between toasted discs of sweetened bread. They haven't a clue what they're eating but the troops can't get enough. Army replenishment is up, but due to frequent toilet stops, movement range is down.

Through a network of informants, this Hero has uncovered an assassination plot against you by a high-ranking traitor. Rather than spook the fiend, the Hero let the conspiracy play out, identifying all collaborators in the process, and leapt before the blade as it was thrust. This character is now wounded, but has gained great experience from their actions.
The example you set is inspirational. The Heroes under your command are proud to carry out your will, and do so eagerly. The cost for all Hero actions has fallen.

In Har Ganeth, the Dark Elf desire for murder and blood is kept in abeyance by the strictest of laws in Naggaroth. Only on Death Night are these laws put on hold and the Druchii permitted to unleash their true instincts. Bloody excess and wanton slaughter flood the boulevards and plazas, all under Hellebron’s intense gaze - tonight is Death Night!

column1: Hellebron will meet the dawn revitalised and strong from the night’s bloody orgy, although over time she will wither once more. In the Death Night’s aftermath her followers are sated, their murderous impulses gratified for now.
column2: true

The extreme humidity 'round 'ere has negatively impacted our army - the rate at which our troops are decomposin' has greatly increased as a result. One has to wonder how much longer they can continue in this climate!
Knowledge Unearthed

The Lords and Ladies of Athel Loren gather every so often to discuss and determine the future of the Asrai. Their word, once the debate is concluded, is proclaimed throughout the forests and enacted immediately. At this moment, they have decided that more funds are required if Athel Loren is to prosper...

A dark deed, one which Isha would not approve even if Ereth Khial does. A potion delivered into a spawning pool will sour the water and stunt Lizardmen growth. This will anger {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}}; leave the phial close by, with the imprint of {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}}.
Dwarfholds are seldom left unguarded, so it would be unwise to try the doors. You back up slowly, in case you trigger a booby-trap left behind by a particularly sharp-witted Engineer.
It is apparent that you have stumbled upon an abandoned Dwarf brewery. Naturally, you take the Dwarfs intoxicating ale and hold a great feast to celebrate your conquests!
Picking the second entrance, you unlock the door and peer cautiously inside. It would appear that you've hit the jackpot - a chest of Dwarfen gold left entirely unguarded!
Ever cautious of Dwarfen ingenuity, you gently push the third door open. Inside, you find a store room bursting with valuable trade goods that can be sold or bartered.
A rush of wind blows you backwards and there is a strange crackle in the air. You notice various runes around the room; this is a Dwarfen trap to nullify magic before it can be used against them!
Unfortunately, as soon as you prise the door open a powder keg explodes, throwing you backwards in the blast. Although the booby-trap failed to kill you, your wounds slow progress.
Cautiously, knowing the Dwarfs capable of laying ingenious traps for the unwary trespasser, you open the third door... to find a room full of beard-grooming products! Bah!
Night of Da Bloody Long Stabbas
Rise of the Thane
The Dragon Crown of Karaz

A Dreadlord of Hag Graef has formed a compact with a Lord of Chaos! Even as he enjoys the dark pleasures his deal has bought, the twisted influence of the Dark Gods insinuates itself across your holdings. As a result, Chaos corruption has risen factionwide.

All eyes turn anxiously to the Isle of the Dead, as the Great Vortex seems to shimmer and slow on its axis. There are fell whispers on the breeze, and all seem troubled in ways they cannot define. As a result, insidious, creeping Chaos corruption has increased factionwide.
Reading the Runes

Some say it is impossible to deceive the Slann, that the great toads perceive all and the reason they do not stop our plots and mummery is that they believe it is all part of their Great Plan – let us test this notion and set {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:FirstTargetFactionName}} and {{CcoCampaignEventIncident:SecondTargetFactionName}} against each other.

The lizard’s inability to tell apart some races - especially the Druchii and Asur - give us an advantage to sour relations. A Sporting Chance

As dawn breaks, and our followers rouse from their dwindling campfires, they discover many of their fellow tribesmen have been turned to mewling spawn. It is a blessing of the Dark Powers!
Stolen Schematics
The Goblins are revolting… well, we already knew that, but they are rioting as well. The little gits should be taught a lesson!

Like malevolent hail, chunks of Warpstone are falling from the sky in certain parts of your realm. Those that survive the onslaught are far from safe or the mutating effects of the Chaos stuff that now scatters the ground.
Good! Distract your people with brutish games. Crowds flock to the fighting pits and arenas to revel in the violence and forget their woes for a time.
Incompetent Escorts

As the slave population has now dropped to barely-sustainable levels, local administrators have outlawed the inhabitants from slaying them at whim. The violent public outcry can be heard clear to the city limits. Public order has fallen as a result!
Spirits are high as a new admiral has been appointed to your fleet.
A network of seditious ne'er-do-wells sows discord in your provinces and public order is falling. Seek methods to remedy this before it erupts into a full-blown rebellion!

A caprice of nature or something more sinister? Either way, this unusually long spell of bitter weather is taking its toll on your armed forces. Replenishment is down, but the appeal of guaranteed rations means new recruits are clamouring to join up, driving down recruitment costs.

While honing his channelling skills, a local Mage-Priest became distracted by some deep rumination. Instead of remotely unleashing a magic missile from the nearby Skink Priest, the Winds of Magic reached critical mass within it, causing the creature's skull to loudly - and very publicly - detonate. The local inhabitants have taken this as a dire omen, and public order has fallen in this province as a result!

A popular troupe of actors has been touring this province, but their performances seem darker and more perverse with each fresh act. Do they dare spread the twisted influence of - whisper it - the Cult of Pleasure? The common gossip suggests as much, yet the authorities do nothing to intervene! As you might expect, public order in this province has decreased as a result.
The inhabitants of your empire tire of the constant threat of war on their doorstep. Due to the uncertainty conflict brings, growth has taken a sudden nosedive.

A celebrity Storm-Vermin pit-fighter has been slain... but not in the ring. The opponent he was due to face was spotted fleeing with a pack of Gutter Runners as his porcupined corpse breathed its last! While such events are commonplace in the warrens, the fans have been denied their sport and that is something that just won't stand; the province is in uproar, and public order has fallen as a result!

The populace in one of your settlements is gradually vanishing! On certain nights, whole ghettos or districts are left abandoned - the only clue for the remaining denizens is a triangular symbol daubed on a nearby gate or wall…
The Saucy Bard
The drought continues. Water has become so scarce it is now worth more than gold or Warpstone! Only those with true power are spared this privation.

As the Blood God knows all too well, war is a meat grinder that constantly requires fresh supplies, which means recruits are not always easy to come by. On this rare occasion, however, there is a glut of bodies, ready and willing to join the fray.
A New Sire
The Eye of the Gods
Only a fool would disturb the dead. The best thing for everyone - living and dead - is that you leave. Now, without further ado.
There are a series of tracks leading away from the graveyard to the North. You follow them and find they lead to a cave filled with hastily-buried chests.
One of the corpses is bedecked in finery and still clutches his weapons. A powerful magical aura emanates from the grave.
Your retainer detects a faint magical signature coming from one of the graves. You dig it up and find a corpse clutching a powerful magical item.
It seems whoever buried the bodies has long since departed and it's unlikely you'd be able to track them down now anyway.
As the corpses are uncovered a strange miasma seeps from among the graves. You should not have disturbed the dead. Now you will pay the price!
There are no traces of magic on these graves, it must've been a trick of the light and nothing more. Let the dead rest in peace.

The Corpse Carts scour the lands - riding into isolated hamlets and taking corpses fresh and foul, smashing through the gates of Morr's garden to plunder the tombs. And now they return to us, the carts full of flesh to be reanimated!
In an effort to impress with his talents, a rising Warlock Engineer skitterleaps from an adjoining chamber directly into your presence. It works! This intrepid Hero is now available for service!
Be the Best!

The appetites of the Halflings are legendary, but now they have nothing left to fill their hotpots. Hisme Stoutheart, Elder of the Moot, is demanding food be shipped in: "We'll make cutbacks, so we only need enough for three courses per meal."
Favoured by the Blood God
Rogue Necromancer Revealed
The dead are best left that way; disturbing corpses is never a good idea. You leave the battlefield at once and pay it no more heed.
Whilst digging a grave for the bodies you find a box buried beneath the ground, inside which is the reward for your compassionate nature.
Most of the equipment has already been looted or destroyed by the victors. However, a corpse, half-buried in the mud, still clutches a most curious item...
There's a collection of what looks like Elven statues inside the warehouse. An art dealer of your acquaintance will be happy to take them off your hands for an excellent price.
You bury the casualties of the battle in a large, shallow grave. You briefly muse on the waste that conflict causes, before dismissing such dangerous thoughts from your mind.
Your retainers quickly establish that the corpses have already been looted - there's nothing of value to be found here.
There's a number of what appear to be Elven statues inside the warehouse. An art dealer of your acquaintance is quick to tell you they are little more than junk, however.

One Good Turn...
Cave-In!

Learnin' that our enemies 'ad equipped 'emselves with state-of-the-art weaponry, we of course set about taking it from 'em wiv haste. One lightnin' raid later an' it is we who now 'ave the advantage - yarrr!
A shrewd programme of stockpiling across your provinces has literally borne fruit, and food-stores are bountifully abundant. The population is in rude health, and growth is on the rise.
Crushed Alive!
Foundations Beset!

What new test is this? The very ground has opened up beneath your Warhird and swallowed up several of your Champions. They must have been weak! Those warriors who remain and did not incur such displeasure must truly be the Chosen of the Gods. They will make your enemies tremble!
Drought

The agent hovers at the entrance until the clamour dies down, then steals inside to witness a scene of devastation. Lizardmen corpses litter the main chamber, but the Crypt Horrors have returned to their swaying, quiescent state. Sensing some kinship with the agent perhaps, they do not attack, but point mournfully toward an alcove where clearly a fine sarcophagus once lay. Alcadizaar's coffin has been spirited away. Tearing a symbol from the tunic of a dead Lizardman, your agent sets out to bring Arkhan the news.

column1: Arkhan is beside himself with anger. What could the perfidious Lizardmen want with Alcadizaar's remains? He smells some species of dark scheme afoot, and demands the Liche Priests bring him news of these interlopers. Through divine communion, the Scavenger-God Ualatp reveals to them the location of the looters. Arkhan wastes no time, and sets out with his army to wrest Alcadizaar's remains from the Lizardmen.

The Winds of Magic swell, so we bathe in their glorious, elemental hues an' bask in the power they imbue. However, it would be wise to note that too much power is invariably difficult to control…

Rapid expansion combined with heavy precipitation has turned the ground surrounding our city walls to quicksand; anyone who passes over it is swallowed by the desert! Although such a thing cannot harm the Unliving, our enemies will struggle to fight us as they are slowly consumed by the sands!
Unnatural Talent

Upon completion of his 200 years service as an apprentice to a Runelord, a Runesmith has left his master, enquired about the sacred forges in the Hold and whether he could have the honour of lighting them again.
There is a distinct lack of able and willing bodies to join your forces for the ongoing wars. Your press gangers, recruiters or straight-up kidnappers are struggling to find "volunteers".

You have instituted defensive training for this army's troops, teaching them to better anticipate incoming blows. All units now have improved melee defence capabilities.
The payment for the slave is made and he is now your rightful property. The information you seek can now be obtained!
Arsenal Acquisition

You waited for the rival salvagers to leave, after which you sent your crew in to take a closer look at the sea beast’s remains. The majority of the loot had already been taken, but fortunately there were a few small sacks of gold left behind to make it worth your effort. These pirates may be greedy and opportunistic, but they weren’t very thorough!

Having decided to wait to discover the fate of the convoy’s wreckage, you eventually receive word that several deadly sea battles took place at the site. Allegedly, very few ships managed to get in and out of the area with anything of any value without being set upon by murderous rivals. In the ensuing chaos, most of the loot ended up at the bottom of the ocean, but your scouts in the area still managed to recover a few valuables from the site.

Knowing that other, more unsavoury individuals may also be drawn to the ‘cursed’ island, you delayed sending in your own small salvage party. The Eternal Realms of Athel Loren are led by great Lords and Ladies, who in turn feel a responsibility for their Elven subjects. Their spirits, and the spirits of the forest, must be kept appeased. And so it is they have thrown great and lavish masques, across the realms, to better bring together the forest and the Asrai. Of course, such ventures are never, ever cheap...

A Khan from the Blasted Wastes has crossed through Death Pass and laid waste to parts of your territory. As is typical of their kind, the cowards have fled back across the World's Edge before we could deal with them properly!
Revere the gods for we need their favour. Yet some fools - insurgents or traitors - are destroying shrines. Doing so risks incurring a holy wrath on us all.
Led by Warrior Priests of Sigmar, and with the blessing of Volkmar the Grim, a force of men under the banner of the Twin-Tailed Comet marches north to engage our servants. Fools!
The coming of the End Times can make allies of bitter enemies and strengthen the bonds of existing friendships.

The earth is more ancient than the Elven race, and seems to favour your primacy. Perhaps it divines the gravity of the mission, and in turn reduces its own, for their troops find marching is easier and less tiring than was previously the case. Campaign movement ranges have increased factionwide as a result.

A wondrous cache of arrows has been discovered, brimming with the power of Asaph, the Goddess of Beauty, Magic and Vengeance! We should arm our archers with this blessed ordnance and send our enemies a rain of death!
Though we're certain that the abilities of our agents far exceed those of the pathetic mortals ranged against us, it's time we gave 'em a chance to prove their skill in anger.

The greatest shock for the Asrai was the discovery that they were not alone in the forests - the Beastmen hordes had made squalid dens amongst the trees. For centuries the two have fought for ownership of the woods. Long have they fought, with not even the climactic Battle of Anguish enough to cease the conflict...

An exquisitely penned history of the Phoenix Lord Bel Shanaar has become widely popular. This artful blending of poetry and prose has caught the imagination of the people and has awakened within them a fresh hatred for Malekith and the foul betrayals of the Druchii. As a result, leadership and melee attack capabilities when facing Dark Elves have risen factionwide.
You have the backing of the Cult of Sigmar. The Warrior Priests preach in the temples and on the battlefields of your divine right to the throne, and so flock to your banner.

A mist rolls down from the mountains covering the lands of Bretonnia. The origin of this dense effluvium is as murky as the mist itself; all the people of Bretonnia know is that what was not there before is there now, obfuscating and obscuring all. Yet more troubling than the mist itself is what lies beyond - the shouting and smashing of the Greenskin hordes haunt the dreams of the peasants, who fear they may be next. The people panic, refusing to leave their homes, lest they be next victims of the slavering, rampaging Orcish host.
